summary: The text discusses the destruction and expulsion of the Jewish people from their promised land, not by the apostles but by the Romans. It emphasizes the judgment that befell them for their role in persecuting spiritual beings and their rejection of the kingdom of heaven. The text parallels the Jewish nation to a barren fig tree that occupies the land, unable to receive the light of truth due to the oppressive leadership of their scribes and Pharisees. This imagery highlights their spiritual barrenness and inability to embrace divine love.
